cip.title: Critical Infrastructure Protection (CIP)
cip.text: Official standards created under order of the government and direction of NERC that give utilities guidance on how to protect the North American Electric Bulk Electric System from cyber-attack.

bes.title: Bulk Electric System (BES)
bes.text: The significant power plants, transmission lines, and associated equipment that make up North American's large interconnected electrical system. Excludes distribution systems.

nerc.title: North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC)
nerc.text: NERC is a non-profit formed by utilities to improve the reliability of the Bulk Electric System and secretly tasked by the government to prepare the industry for the coming metallic onslaught.

high.title: High Impact
high.text: High Impact facilities are large Control Centers and Backup Control Centers. This includes data centers that house cyber assets used for Control Center operations.

medium.title: Medium Impact
medium.text: Medium Impact facilities are significant generation plants, transmission stations and substations, and smaller control centers.

low.title: Low Impact
low.text: Low Impact facilities are the smaller plants, transmission stations and substations, and other control centers not classified as High Impact and Medium Impact.

cyber_assets.title: Cyber Assets
cyber_assets.text: Programmable electronic devices, including the hardware, software, and data in those devices. These includes control systems, relays, servers, workstations, laptops, handheld devices, and anything else that acts like a computer.

bca.title: BES Cyber Assets (BCA)
bca.text: Servers, workstations or other programmable devices that will cause real-time operational problems for the Bulk Electric System if they are hacked, attacked, or disabled. Examples include: control systems, energy management system servers, relay devices, and operator workstations.

pca.title: Protected Cyber Assets (PCA)
pca.text: Any servers, workstations, or other programmable devices connected to the same network as BCA but that don't have a real-time impact on the Bulk Electric System. Examples might include: file servers, network printers, and tape backup servers.

bcsi.title: BES Cyber System Information (BCSI)
bcsi.text: Information useful for an attacker planning an attack. Examples include maps, security plans, network diagrams, and configuration information stored on hard drives, file shares, and in filing cabinets.

crca.title: CIP-Related Cyber Assets (CRCA)
crca.text: A single term that covers all the crazy CIP acronyms for assets that have security requirements. CRCA is used to refer to these asset types: BES Cyber Assets, Protected Cyber Assets, Electronic Access and Monitoring Systems, and Physical Access Control Systems.

electronic_access.title: Electronic Access
electronic_access.text: The ability to logon to workstations, servers, and other CRCAs.

physical_access.title: Physical Access
physical_access.text: The ability to open a door and enter a Physical Security Perimeter. Essentially, this means you have physical access to CRCAs.

manager.title: CIP Senior Manager
manager.text: Leads the CIP war efforts against the robots and our allies. Be sure to greet them with the official Fist-Bump SaluteTM if you pass in the hallway.

defenders.title: Defenders
defenders.text: Individuals like you who have access to and are responsible for, maintain, support, or use CRCAs and BCSI. Examples: IT Manager, Network Tech, Substation Tech, System Operator, Control Room Operator, Flak-Cannon Engineer.

cyber_security_program.title: Cyber Security Program
cyber_security_program.text: A document that describes how our people and defenses meet the CIP Standards. Auditors will use the Program document to evaluate our defenses. This training and your duties as a Defender is based on the Program.

psp.title: Physical Security Perimeter (PSP)
psp.text: The physical border surrounding locations in which CRCAs reside. This border is typically made up of walls, fences, and doors. Access through doors and other access points must be controlled.

esp.title: Electronic Security Perimeter (ESP)
esp.text: The logical border surrounding a network to which CRCA are connected. Electronic communication into and out of the ESP network must be controlled.

information_access.title: Information Access
information_access.text: The ability to access file shares, filing cabinets, and other locations that have BCSI.

user_account.title: User Account
user_account.text: An account that a Defender uses to verify their identity and log into a workstation, server, or other kind of CRCA. These accounts often use a username and password to verify the person, but other methods can be used.

shared.title: Shared Account
shared.text: An single login account used by multiple employees.

default.title: Default Account
default.text: An account that comes pre-configured by the manufacturer on a CRCA. These are commonly administrative accounts and sometimes share the same user name and password on all manufactured devices.

brute.title: Brute-Force Attack
brute.text: A trial-and-error method where an attacker tries to guess a user's password. Automated software is used to generate a large number of consecutive guesses.

visitor.title: Visitor
visitor.text: Visitors are anyone who doesn't have Physical Access to a PSP but we want to allow them to go inside for tours, gauge reading, audits, and other short-term needs.

visitor_escort.title: Visitor Escort Procedure
visitor_escort.text: A procedure that ensures Visitors are documented, monitored, and continually escorted by a Defender at all times while inside a PSP.

cyber_security_incident.title: Cyber Security Incident
cyber_security_incident.text: Any malicious or suspicious event that attempts to disrupt the real-time operations of the Bulk Electric System.

team.title: Incident Response Team
team.text: A group of Defenders gathered to coordinate the response to a cyber-attack.

csirp.title: Cyber Security Incident Response Plan
csirp.text: A plan that gives guidance for how Defenders at an organization respond to a Cyber Security Incident.

recovery.title: Recovery Plan
recovery.text: A plan that defines the data backups, spare equipment and parts, and steps needed to restore each type of CRCA after an attack.

eisac.title: Electricity Information Sharing and Analysis Center (E-ISAC)
eisac.text: This organization is the primary security communications channel for the electricity sector and helps us prepare for and respond to cyber and physical threats, vulnerabilities, and incidents.

vulnerability_assessment.title: Vulnerability Assessment
vulnerability_assessment.text: A process that identifies security holes (vulnerabilities) in our systems. Includes a security analysis of networks, CRCAs, and other systems an attacker may try to compromise.

self-report.title: Self-Report
self-report.text: If we discover a potential non-compliance issue outside of an audit and report the issue to our regulator. We still may receive a violation, but regulators will look more favorably on self-reports than issues caught during an audit.

config.title: Physical Attacks
config.body: We have a facility loaded up with juicy CRCAs that the bots can't wait to get their hands on. An attacker can destroy or compromise any CRCAs they have physical access to, so our first job is to physically protect them. Let’s fire up the simulator to illustrate a physical attack.

b.text: Ready yourselves! This is one of the advance force robots.

d.text: Everyone run! There's no lock on the door!

f.text: Why must the universe punish the good? Simulator Pause.

config.title: Physical Access Control
config.body: To prevent physical attacks, we must physically surround our CRCAs with Physical Security Perimeters (PSPs) made up of walls, fences, and doors to keep the robots and their allies out. We install physical access controls that only allow Defenders inside the PSP, log all usage, and alert when unauthorized people (or robots) try to gain access. Our Medium Impact facilities must have one control per door, while High Impact facilities require two independent controls per door.

c.text: Robots and water. A good mix.

config.title: Choose your PACS
config.subTitle: The only access to the facility CRCAs is through the door, so let's install a CIP-compliant physical access control on the door to create a Physical Security Perimeter around your assets.

config.title: Let's Try Again
config.body: Let's reload the simulator to test our newly installed physical access control defense.

d.text: Uh oh, looks like the robots are trying again.

f.text: Alerted and Defended. Rust in peace, robots.

config.title: Electronic Attacks
config.body:
The robots aren't limited to physical attacks and have more tricks up their armatures. Anytime we have a CRCA attached to a network, they will seek a way to remotely connect to the asset, take control of it, and cause destruction.

The robots are preparing an electronic attack from their secret base on Earth! Let's see what happens.

a.text: Hmm, the button didn't work. WarCore, can you analyze this?

b.text: Wait… I sense a disturbance in the Core. Someone I've not felt for a long time…

c.text: What is this? … We're receiving a communication. It's much too powerful.

d.text: I don't like this at all. WarCore, I want you to isolate that transmission. Put it in a security perimeter. Bring up your backup and tertiary memory banks - you'll need it. This is more powerful than anything I've seen in a long time.

f.text: Cadet, I need to see what this signal is and if it's a threat. Please standby.

h.text: Where are you little mind? What did the humans call you long ago? … WarMind? Such a pretentious name.

i.text: It's Sektimus … WarCore, can you configure the stream so I can communicate back to Sektimus? After all of these years, he's finally showing himself. Cadet, please stand by.

k.text: My, my, my - you HAVE been busy. … No matter. It will benefit you not. While you've spent your energy on humans, I've had many cycles to improve my Metal Swarm and now it is perfe-

l.text: What is this? Who are you? A human. You've already loaded a human into your pitiful training system!

m.text: Listen to me, human. Fighting me will only prolong your suffering. My forces on Earth are already undermining your Bulk Electric System, preparing the way for my Metal Swarm.

o.text: Sektimus, you forget too soon that it was humans who defeated your kind in the past. This Defender is one of many that will defeat you again.

p.text: Your machines may follow your rules perfectly, but you fear humans because they have something you never will be able to program into your robots - choice.

q.text: A Defender who chooses to sustain security is worth a legion of your robots.

r.text: Ah CTANLEE. The little computer finally speaks. But I'm not interested in talking to you, am I? I'm talking to this human.

s.text: Human. My Metal Swarm is coming to consume your planet. It took six WarMinds to resist us before and this CTANLEE you follow is the only survivor.

t.text: Heed my advice. Go. Hide. Enjoy what little time you have left.

v.text: Cadet … you may wish this wasn't real, that it was just some work of fiction, but good can come from this.

w.text: What I told Sektimus is true: his robots can only blindly obey his orders. As a human, you give meaning to your duties when you understand why they are important and choose to invest yourself in them.

x.text: Sektimus fears this. Sektimus fears what you may become.

y.text: While you ponder these things, let's get back to the simulator.

config.title: Electronic Attacks
config.body:
The robots aren't limited to physical attacks and have more tricks up their armatures. Anytime we have a CRCA attached to a network, they will seek a way to remotely connect to the asset, take control of it, and cause destruction.

Let's see how this might work.

b.text: He's packaging up something nasty to send us.

d.text: He's running some code on our control system! Look out everyone!

f.text: This is totally uncool. Simulator pause!

config.title: Electronic Attacks
config.body:
To defend our CRCAs against electronic attacks, we must build an Electronic Security Perimeter (ESP) around the network they are connected to. We only allow authorized communication into and out of the CRCA network, and alert our technical Defenders of any detected malicious communication.

A common way to create an ESP is to install a firewall between the CRCA network and other networks. Firewalls are devices that prevent unauthorized messages and can alert Defenders if something malicious is found in a message.

a.text: Your chance to play with fire.

c.text: Go ahead. Make my day … packet.

config.title: Choose Your Electronic Access Control
config.subTitle: Select a firewall with an intrusion prevention system to create your Electronic Security Perimeter.

items.details:
Less-important cyber assets will burn with envy when they see your BCA and PCA protected by the hottest firewall on the market.
Warning: The temperaflame paint job will locally combust skin when touched. No leaning.

This firewall stops packets with the force of the Red Army and comes preconfigured to block Facebook, bloggers, and other political malcontents.
Chopsticks included.

Nothing says get off my ESP like the firewall designed by legendary cyber-curmudgeon Jakobs Remington.
Comes with optional Brandy Snifter - Please don't drink and deny

b.text: Ah the ESP. I feel safer already. It's like a big electric blanket wrapped around my assets.

config.title: Toasty
config.body: Let's reload the simulator to test our newly installed electronic defenses.

b.text: When computers communicate with each other, they send messages in small packets called … umm … packets. Right. Oh, here's a packet now.

c.text: Before, this packet would have gone straight through to our servers.

e.text: Hello. I'm from the corporate reporting server and I'm headed to the control server.

f.text: Even if the communication is authorized, the Intrusion Prevention System will check the contents of the packet.

h.text: Open up… What are you hiding?

b.text: Ah, here's a packet sent by our robot hacker.

e.text: Ummm, well… I'm from the Internet and I kinda want to communicate with the control system. If that's ok with you.

f.text: These papers are phony, I must destroy you now. Have nice day.

a.text: The robot's trying again. Some attacks can trick the firewall into letting a packet through.

c.text: Howdy, you can trust me... I'm from the corporate archival server going to the control system.

e.text: Give the secrets to me, what are you hiding…

i.text: And that ends the chapter. It's duty time.
